Every day, thouaanda of Iettera and hundrtdt of pounds' worth of valuable articles are en-truated to the aafe keeping of the Egyptian Post Office. All bot the tinieat fraction arrive duly and safely at their destination, »o many that one cornes to take their safety an a matter

course—an a naturel condition of a civilined couimunity, so to npeak. Sometimes, however, thére are exceptioiu to tho wonderful regular-ity with which the machine of the Egyptian postal adminiutretion works, and the new» that nome money or raluablea hâve been in in laid in their course through tlie pont appear» the columnn of tho local newnpapern. From the article which re reprçducc, it will be that tho postal pilferer is far more cunning abroad than in Egypt, but there are black sheep in every flock, and even araong the employés of the Egyptian Post bffict there are now and again fouud nome who fail ictimn to temptation. But they are, we are glad to say, very few and far between, and no administration in Egypt lias such a high levai of integrity atuong ita officiais an the Pont Office. The ntatistics npeak for them-selves, and coùld not be more éloquent For example, huit yesr 1,300,000 registered letten pansed through the Egyptian Pont Office, and yet only six were lost out of this enorroou, number. Thin in an extraordinarily low figure, and compares mont favourebly with the condition of things in Europe, where the average amount of registered lctters lont in twenty-five per million. In the case of innured Iettera the figures are even more favoureble, for during tant year not a single ono was lont Thi, i, duo to the fact . tlist each letter is only pa»<d from one employé to another after a reeript lias been duly signed. Such précautions esnnot be taken in the cane of registered letter* owing to the hilge quantitien pasaing through the post If we compare thin immunity from lonn in the case of innured letter» with the figures for other European cuuntrien it will be

found that the Egyptian Pont Office compare» • very favourebly in thin respect. To take only one examplc. Aocording to the officiai statin-I tics publishcd in a Parisian newnpaper "la Puste," in France 387 innured Iettera were ' lost in the course of one year, and the Post —' Office luul to rcfund the amounts. The value

of the innured articles paasing through the Egyptian Pont Office lait year was £1,000,000 while the specien amounted to £23,000,000. Tliese factn and figures that we hâve just cited arc enough to show the mont nccptical that the work of the Egyptian Poital Administration is being carricd on. in a scrupuloudy careful manner, and that tho organisation and tare with which every départaient is managcl reHect the groatent crédit on the postal autho rities. It in a fact nevertheleas that tho
; Postmantcr General and the Post Office are a • sort of target for ail sorts and conditions of ' complainte roado by all sorts and conditions of people.

div.head: German Training Ship.
div.p: A German training ship was entering Alexandria harbour as we went to press.

div.head: Cairo Printers Strike
div.p: The printers' strike in Cairo is over, a modus cicendi having been come to between both parties.

div.head: Employment Bureau.
div.p: "The Ministry of Finance bas decided to open an employment bureau for foreigners in the course of next month.

div.head: Tho Brindisi Mall
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8 a.m. tomorrow.

div.head: Glanders Epidemic.
div.p: Owing to the epidemic of glanders in Cairo, public water troughs will be closed from December 1st as to check contagion.

div.head: Tho Pilgrimage
div.p: A medical staff of seven physicians, chemists and secretaries, has been appointed for service at Tor during the pilgrimage season.

div.head: Mendloanoy In Cairo
div.p: M. Psychas Acting Hellenic Diplomatic Agent, is said to have take energetic steps to expel Hellenic beggars from the streets of Cairo.

div.head: Kasr-el-Nil Bridge
div.p: Owing to the Skye Meeting on Friday, Kasr-el-Nil Bridge will be open to navigation between 10:30 and 1 p.m., instead of from 12:30 to 3 p.m.

div.head: Wakfs Administration
div.p: The Superior Council of Wakfs meets tomorrow under the presidency of Adly Pasha Yegher, Director General of that Administratration

div.head: Sarraf's Dofalcations.
div.p: Awad Abd El Messih, the sarraf of Nakhon el Batri, Kafr Dawar Markez, recently belied his name and appropriated a considerable sum. He is now in prison--for a year.

div.head: Lift to Pyramids
div.p: Mr. Jacquea Fox, well known engineer, has applied to the Government for permission to consturct an aerial railway from Meda Honra to the top of Cheops Pyremid.

div.head: Cement for Egypt.
div.p: Messrs. Thos. Hinshelwood and Co, Ltd, of Alexandria, have been appointed sole agents for the sale of the Associated Portland Cement Company's "J.B White and Brothera' Brand of Cement" for Egypt and the Sudan.

div.head: Shooting Affray.
div.p: In endeavouring to suppress A drunken brawl in a café at Alexandria last night a member of the secret police force was fired at with a revolver by one of the brawlers, an Algerian, and was removed to hospital in a dangerous condition.

div.head: On the Stump.
div.p: On Thursday next we are to hear Mostapba Posha Kamel hold forth at his school on education and the duty of the people towards their children. Heavens ! Are we to have a new volume of "Egyptiens et Anglais," etc., sprang upon us in the near future ?

div.head: Benefit Performance.
div.p: We would remind our readers of the special performance to be given this evening at the Toor Bifful Mnaio Hall in sid of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association. The programme is a particularly attractive one, and includes a fencing tournament.

div.head: Minieh Agricultural Show.
div.p: Mr. Braun, the new manager of the Grand Continental Hotel, left Cairo yesterday for Minieh to make the necessary arrangements for the banquet which in to be given on the occasion of the inauguration of the Agricultural Show to be held there tomorrow.

div.head: Wrestling Championship.
div.p: The wrestling bouts at the Alhambra Theatre this evening, organised under the auspices of the "Auto" newspaper, are expected to draw a large crowd. The contestants number 16 and include all the colosi who have been distinguishing themselves in Cairo.

div.head: Anti-Tuberculosis League.
div.p: In view of the approach of winter, the Alexandria committee of the Anti-Tuberculosis League appeals for gifts of old clothes for its patients, which will be received either at its dispensaries, 12, rue Tewfick Pash, and Midan rue Gamah Abd el Latif, or ly G. Norgs Bey, treasurer of the League, c/o the Municipality.

div.head: Khedivial Geographical Society.
div.p: A meeting of the K.G.S. will be held in the hall of the Mixed Courts, Cairo, on Friday next, at 3.30 pm, when Dr. Abbate Pasha, the president, will read a paper on "Vesuvior in April 1906. Physiographical Observation and Dr. Bonola Bey will read one on "Geography at the Milan Exposition."

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On the 26th November, 7 vessels, 4 northward and 3 southward bound, transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger toll Fr. 2014-689. Of these vessels, 5 were Britith 1 German, and 1 French. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 7.633.674.97. During this period. 273 vessels transited the Canal, 124 northward and 149 southward bound.

div.head: Motor Boats in Egypt
div.p: The taste for motor boats appears to be growing in this country. Only the other day Sr. G B. Alder on bought a magnificent express motor boat, and now we hear that Ibrahim Bey Cherif has ordered a specially constructed motor dock pump for use on Lake Edkau. Men Dixon Brothers and Hutchinson secured both their orders through their local agents, Messra J.C. Wilcocks and Co.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISTS.
div.p: London, Tuesday, The Times" in it issue today, publishes an important leading article dealing with Egyptian affairs. Whilst commenting favourably on the prospects of the moderate members of the Egyptian Nationalist party having a new European newspaper, it states that it is suspected that the forthcoming launching of a new anti British daily newspaper in Cairo by Mustapha Pasha Kamel is viewed with favour and supported in bigh native circles.

div.head:
AFAYOUM GRIEVANCE
CUTTING OFF THE WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: A Payopin correspondent writes:- I beg to ask for the hospitality of your column in order to raise a protest against the very serious error which the Irrigation Department are abunt to make in this province. It is intended about the 20th of December to close down entirely the Bahr Youssef for a period of thirty days, thos! depriving the whole town and province of Fayoum of its sole source of water supply, with the exception of some more or less disused wells. Putting aside the whole question of the damage to crops involved by this, though it is no light matter for the smaller cultivators whose crops are always later than those of the big proprietors, and whose losses will be considerable in any case, it is a matter of the utmost urgency that the question be re-considered. In the first instance, it is impossible to believe that the Sanitary Department can have sanctioned such a measure as will cut off, I repeat, a whole town and province from its water supply for thirty days. The dregs which will remain in the canals will have become foul and contaminated before half the time has elapsed. Epidemics of some kind are bound to break out, and in many villages the utmost hardships will be inflicted on both man and beast. In writing this letter I am anxious to avoid appearing to cast ondue blame on the Irrigation Department, whose principal object in deciding to close for this period is in order to avoid the extra expense involved in completing the work in two installments, as it were. But, Sir, I submit that this is no occasion for economy of such a nature which is both false and misplaced, and I earnestly appeal to the powers that be to prevent this, which is almost a crime, from taking place.

div.head: SUDAN OFFICE.
div.p: We are authorised to state that the rumour poblished by several of ont contemporaries, to the effect that Miralei R. Owen Bey, C.M.G, is to be tran-ferred from the Sudan Office to the War Offi e as Under Secretary of State, is totally incorrect. There is no change contemplated in the War Department, and Owen Bay still retains the post to which he was appointed on the transfer barly this year of Lord Elward Ceoil Pa-hs to the Ministry of Finance, viz. Agert for the Sudan Govern. mert and chief of the Intelligence Department.

div.head: HISTORY OF SINAI.
div.p: We hear that Nacom Bey Shokeir, secretary to the Frontier Commision, is at work on a history of the Sinni Peninsula, which will be publi-bed next spring. The excellence of Naoum Bey's "History of the Sadan" is a gas. rantee of the value of his next literary production.

div.head: THE MIXED COURTS.
div.p: At tomorrow's Coonoil of Ministera, the nomination of three foreign judge-Swedish Nowegians, and Portuguese to the Mixed Courts will be sobmitted for approval.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: The pob.committee appointed on Monday Last to elaborate the scheme for the con version of the National Bank of Egypt into A State Bank, will submit its report to the directors of the National Bank in a fortnight's time, and the report will be onsidered at the following usoal Monday meetidg of the Board, It is gauerally considered in well-informed circles that the project is bound to go throngh

div.head: SALT AND SODA CO.
div.p: There is no teath in the rumour that the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company intend to open negotiations with the Port Said Salt Association with a view to fnsion.
There will be a general meeting of the shareholders of the company on the 27th inst. to consider the proposed payment of & 71 per cent, dividend.

div.head: THE LATE DR. NIMR.
div.p: As announced, the toneral of the late Dr.! Nicolas Nimr, who pasred away on Sunday night, took place with much folemnity on Monday afternoon. "The pall bearers were Shukour Pashs, Isa Pasha Hamdy, Hosein Pa-ha Shoukri, Colonel Dr. Moussalla Bey Boutros Bey Mescines, Skander Bey Dimitri, and Antoon Bey Sabbagh. Messages of condelence were received by the bereaved family
from Mo-tay ba Pogba Pebmy, Princess Nsz'i H em, Lord Cromer, Mr. Boyle, Mr. Machell, Mr. Mitchell Inner, Sir Horace Pipcbing. Bernard Pachs, Mirelai Owen Bey, Pathy Pasha Zazhlool, and others.

div.head: MARIOUT FLOODED.
div.p: The terrible weather that has visited Alexandria and the neighbourhood doring the past few days bas fallen with great violenre on the Marioot district, where the damage has been widespread. The wasb-outs on the Khedive's railway bave been serious, and the line between Amrich and Kingi-Mariont has been destroyed.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Kbedive, who is spending to-day at Koobbeh Palace, will come in to-morrow morning to Abdeen, where he will preside at the Conncil of Ministers. In the evening his Highness will give a barquet in honour of M. de la Boulinière, the departing Prench Consnl Goneral in Cairo, who has been transferred to Athens
On Friday the Khedive will attend midday prayer at Al Hasaeini Morqae.

The Khedive has granted a special audienop to Dr. Zis al-Din Abmed, an Indian visitor & note, who is leaving for Aligarb, where he is * proferror in the Mohamedan University. His Highness presented Dr. Ahmed with his portrait

On Sunday, being the birthday of Prince Abdol Moneim, the Heir Presemptive, a depotation of the Higher Schools Clob, headed by! Omar Bay Looth, waited on his Highness and presented their congratulations.

div.head: TRANSPORT REWA REPLOATED.
div.p: H.M.T. Rewa, which grounded in the Capal yesterday morning and blocked the passage, was only reflosted at 8.30 tbis morning at high tide with the assistance of tbe powerfal tog Titan. She proceeded to Port Said soon after without apparently sastaining any damage. The Canal is now clear for traffio after a stoppage of about 20 hours.
Surz experienced yesterday & very heavy rainfall. It rained continually for about two hours, but later on the weather cleared up, althoagh it is not quite settled yet.

div.head: CAFFARI'S CO-OPERATIVE MARKETS, LTD.
div.p: The first full board meeting of the above company took place in Cairo last week under the obsirmanship of Maltre Bm. Manuaardi, the other directors present being Messrs. Charles Grandjean, Jules Sobutz, Paul Oziol, Phillippe Garoza, and John B. Caffari, the managing director. It was decided to make the first poblio izgue of £15,000 of Ordinary £1 shares on the 17th December, the founders having themselves sabeoribed to the extent of the remaining £25.000, the total share capital of the new company, which was incorporated on the 27th August being £40,000. After ve:ifying the books and account of the compady for the period commencing from the 15th of Jane last to date, the Board was entirely satisfied and pleased with the resolts already shown of this new undertaking, including those of the market. The latter, which were only opened on the lat instant, are already a great succesa, and are daily becoming more popular with the general public as they meet a long følt want and are sitaated in the very heart of the lamailia quarter. Here most, fisb, vegetablo«, and other household requisites of the very first quality are sold and the premises are kept soropalously clean, being under Eaglistrsapervision.

At the close of the meeting a vote of thanks to Mr. John B Caffari was unanimously passed for bir energy and ability in founding and working with such marked 3000888 this important enterprise, unique of its kind in Ezypt. Immediately after the Cairo establishment bus been properly organised and in full working order the Alexandria branch of the bosiners will be converted into a similar one to that at Crito, and a general market will be established bere too. We mentioned in our isste of the 30th ultimo the many advantages offared to the publio in dealing with these stores; the foremost is the convenience of being able, by one walk throngh the extensive premises in Sharia Ksar-el-Nil, to prccore all one's bongohold needs in one place and be sure of getting everything of the best quality and at the most moderate pride. We shall pablish in the oqarga of the next few days the prospectus of the company in extenso.

div.head: KENEH STATION.
div.p: to the fact that Keneh station is "miterably lit," and in this respect compares very un. lavourably with other stations of its class, like those of Sohag and Leixor, which are splendidly lit by electric light. The light in use in Keneh station at present, he Faye, is totally inadeI quate and pot in keeping with the traffio

htch goes through it. In commercial import! ance Keneb station ranks among the first of its class. Oor correspondent also refers to the existence of rots in the asybalt platform of the Atstion, which are a atanding danger to pas. sengers getting ont of the trains.
In every big station there is a farrash #pecially delegated to look after its cleanliness And the trimming of the lampa. At Keneh station, bowever, we are informed, there is no soch official.

div.head:
GHAZI MUKHTAR PASHA.
TURKISH PRESTIGE IN EGYPT.
div.p: Damanhoor, Monday. Yerterday meruing, shortly after 10 o'clock, I wanted to go to the down platform at Dam phoor station, and was much astoniabed to find a great commotion everywhere. The officials and employés of the Egyptian Ad. pinistration were in a state of extraordinary portarbation, while the bridge over the rail. way line, and the approaches to the station, despite the atrocios weather, were orowded with natives in a state of tremolous excitement.

I at least thought some special occasion had occurred, which bad induced the Kbedive to unexpectedly pay a visit to Damanhoor, for I have never been such interest taken in the passage of his Highness through DAmapbour as WAB manifested yesterday. In foot the crowd and the officials of the railway appeared to be far more impressed than is ever the case when his Highness passes hero in his special train on the two occasions of]. the year when he retorns to and departs from Alexandria.

I asked a native porter what was the matter, and he told me that "the Basba" was passing! through Damabhoor on his way from Alex. 1 andria to Cairo. I naturally thought the man re'erred to his Highneag, and when I interregatively replied, "Abbag Pasba 1"' the man shook his head and exclaimed "No; it is the great Ghazi Mohktar Pashs, the representative of our own Saltan ja Egypt." The man rolled out the Gbazi's rank and titles with an : upotuous and reverent earnsetnes which would have been pot out of place if he had been speaking of the Zilleh-i-Alah of Yildiz. I was sorprised, although I have been born and bred in this country, for the man epoke as though he was absolotely convinced that the Ghazi was the supreme arbiter of Egypt's destinies inasmuch as he was the Imperial

Commissioner of the Caliph. In the case of Jan anedoosted tellab this attitude is excusable, but I was entirely taken aback when I found that the officials in the service of the Egyptian Railway Administration at an important sta tion, as is Dampaaboar, ahoold slao regard his i Excellenoy as a facrosanot personage.

I passed on, as I wanted to take my ticket at the station, and made my way to the door of the station. But I found it closed and was informed that no tickets were being inged, although my traia was soon dae I asked the railway employé the reason, and be said that it was obligatory that I should wait until the Gbazi bad pasaed by in his special train. I therefore crossed over the bridge, making my way with the atmost difficulty through a trantio throng of enthusiastic natives, who, soaked in the pooring rain and bespattered in the deep mad, did not for a moment allow their zoal to be checked by the appropitious weather. I at last found a rofage in the buffet! until the Pasba's train oame ap. The platform was lined with the entire forda of policemen that Damanhonr oan boast of. When the Paabs passed the enthusiasm reached boiling point. The mob yelled and shouted with eostatio enthusiasm, which was amosing owing to i the fervent manner in which it was expressed. I am sure his Bxcellenoy moat bave been delighted, and I wonder if he received a similar ovation at the other towns along the line.

I should like to know whether the Egyptian Railway Administration sends strict instrootion to its station master to take such messores ng shotting the platforms and booking offices to intending passengers when the Gbazi pasien. Does the Ministry of the Interior explicitly order the Moudit of the Behera to bring op all the police to the platforms as though the Khedivo were visiting the town in state. The nataral conelosion which the ignorant populace draws from all this honour is that the hero of the Tabsb affair is the most potent force in the political world of Bgypt, and that the Egyptian Government is more desirous of paying honour to the Turkish official than to the Khedive, for there was far greater to-do" at Damanboor yasterday thap wben the Khedive came through here on Saturday last. How is it that euch efforts are made to exalt the prestige of an Ottoman fanctionary who has no definite official daties in this country, and, although a most excellent and able old gentleman and soldier, is nothing more por less than a political anonmbrance? As Lord. Milner said, he is "technically an anomaly" for he does not represent tha Saltan, 89 the Kbedivel himself is the representative of the Sultan in Bzypt. A great deal of the enthusisam I witnosed was doubtless due to the panegyrica of the vernacular Pres indulged in a few month ago on the wonderful diplomatio victory that the old Ottoman warrior bad gained over Lord Cromer in his stroggle to maintain the jast claims of his master, the Caliph, against the impodent pretensions of Great Britain on the Sinaitiu frontier !

As I sat musing in the drizzle on Daman. honr platform, as the Ghazi's train was approaching. I thought of an incident that oscurred close to that very station a few days praviously, when a sprcial tourist train on its way to Cairo was pelted outside the station by a mob of Damanhour people (not fellabeen) with tones and filth. There were members of the Effendi cines close by who looked on at this abameful exbibition of fanatical batred against Boropeans and they never made the slightent remonstrance.

div.p: CAIRO. Bailt in 1804, Modern Hots. Splendid situation. Kectrlo Lighs

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON.
div.p: What a change 1 M. Poncet, instead of "ces messieura" and French opera, instead of Italian. The difference was notable. M. Ponoet bas evidently selected a good, reliable com pany. I have yet to bear the chanteurs and chanteuses nobles ; but the "demi-caractères" and the light voicen promise well. Mlle. Char. pontior is quite excellent; 'her voice is sweet and carries well, and has great flexibility, and when required she can introduce all the warmth and sabtlety one can desire. Her acting is pretty and appropriate. It sbe sings the part of Louise in Charpentier's opera it! abould be s 800008. M. Durand is a typical and most useful barse chantante"; and M. Loreo has a charming high baritone. M. Fontaine, tenor *demi caractère," WA not good till the third act : be kept singing fist and was far too mach given to mannerisms, and not well made op. He seems to have a good range of noter, but in all bot the most passionate parts be it rather hard, and not so pleasing or snpple as would be an Italian of the same quality of voice. The choros is fair, and not so appallingly thin and ready as that of last year. The conductor and orchestra seem very good. The third act was bandle with the greatest poesible delicacy. Indeed the third act as a whole was the best part of the per formanos. The constant use of spoken dialogue, the lightness of the acting characterised the piece: how they will do, say, "Rigoletto" or "Trouvère," we have yet to see. Saveral times thy acting and dialogoe were exactly what was needed to sava the sitoation. M. Martè, for instance, as Guillot, was admirable for that very reason. His voice does not seem very adequate, but it never came in question; he managed the whole part cleverly enough to evade any weakness, The scenery and décors were good, bat then on that one point the Khedivial Theatre always is good.

Altogether it seems qaite promising and if Becalais (he is opwell at this moment) is all we have board, we may have some really fine operas. "Sigurd," for example, and Samson and Dalila" are both great pieces. And in any case it is a delightfal change after the Beoond rate, happy-go-lucky wixtures of the last two years. Of course the caste is the same old story: singers from provincial towns select-1 ed at the last moment, with one or two who may become or have been atars, to leaven the lamp. Bat happily the French provincial singer is well taught and hard working, and as often as not is a really good actor as well; be bas not the same fatal facility of voice as his Italian rival (I would except the average good olass bags of baritone), but he is generally more in keeping | with his part. Mediocrity-f it is to be medio crity - will at least be pleasing this year, and not aggressive.

Mme. Jane Hading brought her all too abort a season in Bgypt to a close yesterday evening by a performar ce at the Zizinia of Obnet's popular "Le Maitre de Forgos," in whicb, it ia needless to say, she was perfect, notwith standing that she was labouring ander the disadvantage of a severe oold.

div.head: AT SHEPHBARD'S.
div.p: Monday's danga at Shepheard's would have been a very great success bad there been more of the gentler sex present. The floor was perfoot, and the musio most allaring; but alas! there were far too fow ladies to provide partners for the gentlemen, who tarned up in great force. Of course it is early yet to expect the usual crowd that throng the ball-rooms in the height of the souton, and the great improvemopts in the arrangement of this hotel will doubtlesn be all the more appreciated in a few weeks! time. Long, thick curtains now hang across the ball before the front door, keeping out every suspicion of a draught ; and the new roomy alcove close to the Egyptian Hall is a very great addition to the sitting ont accommodation. The ladies' dressing room has also been greatly enlarged and improved.

But those ladies who were present in the ball-room on Monday night had no lack of partners, and dancing was in full swing till after midnight. The superb decoration of the Egyptian Hall is always a wonderful setting for opiforms and pretty frocky, and the sceno I on this occasion was all the prettier for not being overcrowded. H.R. H. the Duke of Cumberland was present for a while, as also Was Sir Richard Temple. Mrs. Rom was sur rounded by a group of friends to welcome her on her recent arrival, and many other familiar faces were to be seen.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S CORNICHE.
div.p: One of the most important improvements contemplated at Alexandria is the making of a corniche road along the Romleh Riviera from Alexandrin. Kamel Boy Teymour intendo making an interpellation on tbis suljest at tomorrow's meeting of the Municipal Commission.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Sailor Prince, with passer gers and general cargo, lett Manchester on the 26:b inat, and is doe at Alexandris on or about the 11th December.
The 8 S. Creole Prince, with passengers a d general cargo, arrived at Manchester yesterday from Alexandria.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Omar Pasha Toussoon and Prince Aziz Pasha Haaran left Alexandria yesterday afternoon for Cairo.
Lady Cromer and the Hon. Evelyn Baring have arrived at Mena House Hotel
Io view of M. de la Boaliuid.e's departure from Cairo on December 2, a committee has been formed among the Prench colony to organise farewell demoustration in his honour.
M. B. Dioey, C.B., is expected to arrive at Cairo to-day, coming by the Brir disi mail, and will stay at Shepheard's.

Professor Sxyce arrived in Cairo on Monday and delivered a lecture on "Bzypt and the Pentateuch" to the Church of Bagland Travel Guild at the Khedivial Hotel on Tuesday evering. The Professor is staying at Charob Hoone and will pranch on Sanday morning at All Saints' Chorob. Service begios at 10.30 am
Wo are glad to report some improvement in the state of Mme. Barois, wife of the President of the French Benevolent Sociaty, who has been seriogaly ill for some days.

All the rank and fashion of Alexandria were present at Saint Catherine's Cathedral this morning in order to attend the marriage of Miss Mary Ricard, the daughter of M. Joles Ricard, the popular and respested agent of the Mosssgeries Maritimes Steam Navigation Con. pany at Alexandria, to M. Hippolytus Ber. gaase. The Cathedral was orowded with a large Assemblage and leading representatives of all the various Boropean colonies were present. A reception followed at the Now Kbedivial Hotel. Among those present were Mustapha Pasba Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, Saba Pasha, the Postmaster General, members of the Consolar Corps at Alexandris, etc., etc.

Dr. Wild accompanied by Mr. Wild, has returned to Cairo from Barope and resumed his duties of medical officer of the Desooneses Hospital, which position he has ably filled for apwards of 20 yeara. Daring Dr. Wild's absence the work at the hospital was under the charge of Dr. A. Hegi.
Mr. and Mra. Maloolm Aird have left Cairo for Bineb, accompanied by Mr. Joha Blue.
Captain Wilson, R.A.M.O., and Mrs. Wilson have taken up their quarters for the season at the Continental Hotel

Mr. James Henry Smith, of New York, who has been shooting with Sir George Cooper at Winchester, bas gone to Paris, to rejoin Mrs. Smith prior to proceeding to Egypt, where they intend to remain orer Cbristmas.
Mr. W. Roghó, of the Nizam Office, Alex. Andris Gouvernorat, bas applied for his pension. He is to be succeeded by Selim Bffendi El Assanad.

LIBBKAL PARTY IN DANGER.
MR CHURCHILL'8 APPBAL

div.p: Mr. Winston Churchill, speaking et Hod-

Tbe bnlk of the imported liqaora cooiiat» of bigb olaaa bottled liquor», prinoipally well-koowo brands c f whisky, brandy, beer, and ligbt wioae. Otber bottled apirits end wioea are imported in cases of one de ceo, weigbiDg eenh 50 lb., or rather more. Hence a ton of bottled spirite or wioea (for inatanoe, vhûky, brandy, olaret, or champagne) containa 44 dr-MO. Whiaky at P.T. 2(0 a case comea to L E 88 a ton. Tbe great rite in price be'wein the vaine of the liquora io the year 1901 and the follow-ing yetra is attributable to the estimate for the year 1901 haviogbeeo made on an average priee of L.B. 36 a ton, which ia estimated as the average vaine at which «nch l'quora woold be aaaeaaed at Alexandrie for Coatoma. Concession! de Terrainsa Bâtir a Port-Soudan
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'environ 400 parcelles de terrains k bâtir à Port-Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données k bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années à partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, à charge pour le locataire de bktir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'à partir, de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loyer variablo fixé à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmentation do loyer.

EXEMPLE : Si une parcelle de teraain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à f rtir du 1er Janvier 1907. Dans co cas, à l'exapiretion de ce délai, lo locataire aura un droit (à condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi à perpétuité.
I» loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il {tait libre de construction.

Des offics sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotique, dont s'agit ; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que lo soumissionairo est disposé à payer au comptant en sus dos loyers annuels établis pour chacun des Iota. Is» dite prime devra être payée en uu seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressée» par lo Gouverne-meht du Soudan, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum avant lo 1er Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, le» conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession. In formule de soumission, spécifies tion du bail, seront à la disposition du Public à partir du lcr Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*—Bureau du Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire* Bureau de l'agent du Gouvernement du Houdan (T).
Souakim—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rougo.
Wadi Haïfa—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Prorince de Halfa.
El-Darocr— Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berbcr.
Atbara—Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Port-Saïd—Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres—Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Impérial Institute.
Suex—Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
